abstract: The financial giant Bank of America says it is no longer lobbying the federal government about its unfolding bank bailout. After receiving $45 billion in bailout money, lobbying was just too unseemly.
lead_paragraph: The financial giant Bank of America says it is no longer lobbying the federal government about its unfolding bank bailout. After receiving $45 billion in bailout money, lobbying was just too unseemly.

headline.main: Firms That Got Bailout Money Keep Lobbying

abstract: Bank of America played a role in Merrill Lynch‘s controversial decision to pay $4 billion in bonuses in December, a move that was said to have contributed to the ousting of John A. Thain from the newly merged bank, The Financial Times reported.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America played a role in Merrill Lynch‘s controversial decision to pay $4 billion in bonuses in December, a move that was said to have contributed to the ousting of John A. Thain from the newly merged bank, The Financial Times reported.

headline.main: BofA Played Role in $4 Billion Merrill Bonuses, Report Says

abstract: John Thain is defending his actions on several fronts as he makes his exit from Bank of America. But the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch is sounding a bit contrite about that $35,000 commode.
snippet: John Thain is defending his actions on several fronts as he makes his exit from Bank of America. But the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch is sounding a bit contrite about that $35,000 commode.
lead_paragraph: John Thain is defending his decisions on several fronts as he makes his exit from Bank of America. But Mr. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch, is sounding a bit contrite about that $35,000 commode.

headline.main: Thain Defends Actions, But Will Pay for Renovations

abstract: According to the Dow, I.B.M. is more important than Citigroup, General Electric, General Motors, Bank of America, JPMorgan, Alcoa and American Express — combined.
snippet: According to the Dow, I.B.M. is more important than Citigroup, General Electric, General Motors, Bank of America, JPMorgan, Alcoa and American Express — combined.
lead_paragraph: I’ve made the case before that the Dow Jones industrials average is often a misleading measure of the stock market. The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is more relevant, both for professional investors and for those of us who own mutual funds.
